relatedanime.anime: Koukyoushihen: Eureka Seven - Pocket ga Niji de Ippai

recommendations.recommendation: A nice anime, with a good story, but there are a lot of flaws in it. It is still enjoyable though.
Absolutely terrific

This is probably the most enjoyable series I have had the pleasure of watching over the years. Objectively there are better written shows out there, but Eureka 7 combines conflicted yet likable characters, a great/unique story that keeps getting better, with impressive animation. A+++
Great story and awesome chars. Recommended to all of those who thought by mistake Code Geas was the best mecha serie out there
This is aGREAT series start to finish. 50 Episodes and not one is waster or filler.
Annoying start, epic end
Nice !
A great series with something for everyone.

If you like mache and romance then watch this. It is pure romance between teens so not for adult if your looking for something more extreme. Main character is weak and look stupid. The theme of this anime is love conquer all lol. I hope you like it.
good anime with good story and good action ... series worth seeing :)
i really suprised from these series, definitely worth your time!
If you liked Evangelion, you`ll LOVE this one. This takes the deep philosophical edge of EVA and goes many steps beyond.

first anime which touched my heart
unlimited amounts of love, and this is mecha of course, but there`s more romantic aspect. And note, i`ve been 18 year old when watched this
Watch this. People who don`t buy into the "contrived romance" (which it isn`t) don`t have hearts. Seriously. Just do it, now.
I realle love this anime...A MUST SEE ANIME...
A lovely anime with an epic & engaging story, great & lovable characters, and a somewhat unique concept. Loved it from beginning to end.
probly one of the best anime in terms of character devolpement, story and awesome music that fits the show perfectly
Perfect
A flawless work of art, exhilerating from start to finish.
More than just the best mecha series; it`s the best of everything it even tries to touch on.
Definitely recommend. I wont list all the reasons why it`s great, but a couple should be enough. Epic Love and Plot Continuity.

This anime was the first in quite some time, that made me cry. The plot is touching and dramatic, it makes you think about the important things in life. All that along with great animation and fantastic soundtrack definitely make it a must see !
Just watch it.
simply epic, from bit akward and slow start to booming end. <3 last 10 or so ep`s is just epicness all over the place

the first 3 episodes left me as excited, happy and moved as no other Anime Series before :)
Definitely check it out!
I`m still grinning from watching :D
Like no other. I`ve truly enjoyed all the 50 episodes. Believe me, if you are watching this, you are doing yourself a great favor!

if your new to anime put this on your list it don`t mater if you get English or Japanese audio both are really well done and that alone makes a big impact a easy 8 of 10 in eng or 9 of 10 in jap i speak and read both and do some subbing my self and after 200+ series this is still in my top ten
It was an awesome series! Sometimes weird, sometimes slow, sometimes sad, and other times funny, but did these with good balance... mostly... I did find the ending unnecessarily surreal though...
Really unique story and characters with inspiring visuals.Anyone treasures their childhood dreams and friendships should love this.One of my TOP 10 anime of all time!

one of the best animes i`ve seen, and i`ve seen a lot... great combination of character development, story, animation and sound
and i actually don`t like mecha and robots animes...

you wont regret it

anime.description: A 14-year-old named http://anidb.net/ch2874 [Renton] lives with his mechanic grandfather. His life is thrown somewhat off-kilter when a mech called http://anidb.net/ch2958 [Nirvash] crashes into his house one day and a young girl called http://anidb.net/ch2875 [Eureka] pops up asking for help to repair it. Shortly after, the military mechs get involved...

externalentity.identifier: 交響詩篇エウレカセブン

tag.name: maintenance tags
tag.description: These tags are used for maintenance.

tag.name: military
tag.description: The military, also known as the armed forces, are forces authorized and legally entitled to use deadly force so as to support the interests of the state and its citizens. The task of the military is usually defined as defence of the state and its citizens and the prosecution of war against foreign powers. The military may also have additional functions within a society, including construction, emergency services, social ceremonies, and guarding critical areas. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: bounty hunter
tag.description: A bounty hunter is one who hunts and captures targets (be it people, animals, etc.) for monetary gain, preferably without killing/destroying their target. Despite being illegal in most of the world today, it is a legal profession in the United States and Philippines (a former commonwealth of the US), who are known as "bail enforcement agents". If they are only and constantly hired to kill, they are likely an http://anidb.net/t2399 [assassin]. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: shounen
tag.description: In the context of manga and associated media, shounen, literally meaning "youth" and often also specifically "boy", refers to a male audience roughly between the ages of 10 and 18. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: megalomaniac
tag.description:
Megalomania is a psychopathological condition characterized by delusional fantasies of power, relevance, and omnipotence, and by inflated self-esteem.
Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: photography
tag.description: Photography is the art or process of producing images by the action of radiant energy and especially light on a sensitive surface (such as film or an optical sensor). Source: Merriam-Webster

tag.name: pirate
tag.description: Pirates are people who attack ships on the high seas to rob others of their treasure. Well, at least usually. Other people calling themselves pirates are not unheard of, usually focusing on the freedom and romance involved in the piracy-related tropes and cliches. They may or may not be after the One Piece or a spaceship full of diamonds, too, if that`s what they see as treasure. Real-life pirates were extremely common a few centuries ago, and countries even sponsored their own pirates, called "privateers", to attack ships with flags of other countries. Nowadays, however, very few actual pirates still exist, and they rely more on terrorism and guerrilla warfare than anything else, demanding ransom in exchange for hostages instead of openly attacking the enemies with their swords. Another, more modern meaning for the word refers to people who illegally download copyrighted works they are not entitled to have a copy of. Be whichever it may, there are pirates around here. Arr, avast! Thar be pirates in these dark waters, matey!

tag.name: tentacle
tag.description: A tentacle or bothrium (plural: bothria) is one of usually two or more elongated flexible organs present in animals, especially invertebrates. Usually, Tentacles are used for feeding, feeling and grasping.

tag.name: immature
tag.description: Marked by or indicating a lack of maturity

tag.name: child soldier
tag.description: Untrained and as yet immature, children are expediently thrust into the role of warriors to protect god, king, and country. Not having even finished school, they are inexplicably designated to elite status or roles, typically requiring months of training and years of experience. All the more so with "experimental" equipment or weapons of mass destruction.

tag.name: flying
tag.description: This character has wings, natural or artificial, which enable the character to take flight. Or is in command of some form of levitation (e.g. a witch using a broom to fly). Not to be confused with "flying planes" or "flying helicopters".

tag.name: air force
tag.description: An air force, also known in some countries as an air army or air corps, is in the broadest sense, the national military organization that primarily conducts aerial warfare. More specifically, it is the branch of a nation`s armed services that is responsible for aerial warfare as distinct from an army, navy or other branch. Typically, air forces are responsible for gaining control of the air, carrying out strategic-bombing missions and providing support to surface forces. The term "air force" may also refer to a tactical air force or numbered air force, which is an operational formation within a national air force. Air forces typically consist of a combination of fighters, bombers, helicopters, transport planes and other aircraft.

tag.name: mercenary
tag.description: A mercenary is a person who takes part in an armed conflict who is not a national or party to the conflict and is "motivated to take part in the hostilities by desire for private gain". Mercenaries fight for money or other recompense rather than for political interests. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: alien
tag.description: This entity or creature was born on another world than the main characters.

tag.name: robot
tag.description: A robot is an automatically guided machine, able to do tasks on its own. Another common characteristic is that by its appearance or movements, a robot often conveys a sense that it has intent or agency of its own. Not to be confused with android (human-like robot).

tag.name: content indicators
tag.description: The content indicators branch is intended to be a less geographically specific tool than the `age rating` used by convention, for warning about things that might cause offence. Obviously there is still a degree of subjectivity involved, but hopefully it will prove useful for parents with delicate children, or children with delicate parents. Note: Refer to further guidance on http://wiki.anidb.net/w/Categories:Content_Indicators [the Wiki page] for how to apply tag weights for content indicators.

tag.name: dynamic
tag.description: Some of the central structural elements in anime are: Plot Continuity How does the plot or several plots unfold. Are they a strictly linear retelling of one big continuing story, a serial, possibly with several side stories, or is the content chopped into a set of unconnected episodes, only sharing the same setting and characters? Stereotype Characters Then there is the question of the character set presentation. Is it completely original, or is it your usual stereotypical character cast. Both choices have their merit, for example it would not really make much sense to reinvent the wheel for a harem anime. Fans of that genre come to expect their favourite stereotype protagonists. Plot Twists Finally there is the question of how complex the plot / the story unfolds. Are there side-plots that merge into the main plot leading to unexpected plot twists, or is the anime quite predictable? The latter would not be appropriate for detective stories. In harem anime on the other hand a foreseeable outcome is actually something the fans will come to expect.

tag.name: target audience
tag.description: Anime, like everything else in the modern world, is targeted towards specific audiences, both implicitly by the creators and overtly by the marketing. While categories are associated with specific sex and age groups, this is not a bar on the anime being enjoyed by people who don`t fit into that band; not only do crossover titles exist, but the categories also have a considerable following outside their main demographic, and a person might as well enjoy anime from all categories. Still, does not invalidate the usefulness of marking a title as one of the categories; the same themes will likely be treated differently in anime geared for different audiences. Only one should not jump the gun and assume that a title will be more or less serious or present content in this or that way due to its target audience, or conversely assume the target audience on the content and its presentation alone. As such, the audience categories help form a broad impression of how a title might work with the announced themes, but offer little to no in-depth information about specific content or its treatment. The audience categories originate from manga magazines, which group titles of a same intended audience into a magazine that is advertised as belonging to that category, and so manga-based anime will have the category from their parent work. As for anime based on other works, the audience is often debatable, but comparing information such as time slot to the manga-based anime generally helps figure out the most likely possibility. If the parent material was classified under multiple audiences over time (for example, it was originally shounen, but then as the plot changed and became more mature, it was reclassified as seinen), and the anime adapts parent material time periods covering multiple audiences, we tag all audiences covered by the anime adaptation.

tag.name: themes
tag.description: Themes describe the very central elements important to the anime stories. They set the backdrop against which the protagonists must face their challenges. Be it School Life, present Daily Life, Military action, Cyberpunk, Law and Order detective work, Sports, or the Underworld. These are only but a few of the more typical backgrounds for anime plots. Add to that a Conspiracy setting with a possible tragic outcome, the Themes span most of the imaginable subject matter relevant to anime.

tag.name: fetishes
tag.description: Everything under fetishes (except for Bishounen and Juujin) is strictly only meant for hentai (18 Restricted) and ecchi anime. In case of ecchi, it must be the main element of the show and not when there`s only some of it, for example, there`s some ecchi in Shinseiki Evangelion, but the fact you get to see Asuka`s pantsu doesn`t warrant it the schoolgirl fetish category. So be careful to which ecchi show you add fetishes; it`s fairly straightforward with hentai, though. Overall, this category tree is to satisfy the needs of people with different fetishes, so they can search for what tingles their tangle; hence why this is restricted to hentai and full ecchi shows.

tag.name: original work
tag.description: What the anime is based on! This is given as the original work credit in the OP. Mostly of academic interest, but a useful bit of info, hinting at the possible depth of story.

tag.name: setting
tag.description: The setting describes in what time and place an anime takes place. To a certain extent it describes what you can expect from the world in the anime.

tag.name: elements
tag.description: Next to Themes setting the backdrop for the protagonists in anime, there are the more detailed plot Elements that centre on character interactions: "What do characters do to each other or what is done to them?". Is it violent Action, an awe-inspiring Adventure in a foreign place, the gripping life of a Detective, a slapstick Comedy, an Ecchi Harem anime, a SciFi epic, or some Fantasy travelling adventure?

tag.name: time
tag.description: This placeholder lists different epochs in human history and more vague but important timelines such as the future, the present and the past.

tag.name: place
tag.description: The places the anime can take place in. Includes more specific places such as a country on Earth, as well as more general places such as a dystopia or a mirror world.

tag.name: calling your attacks
tag.description: "GIGAAAAAA DRIIIIIILLL BREAKEEEEEERRR" If you can do something more impressive than just throw a punch, your attack(s) must have an equally impressive name. More than that, you have to call it out as you launch the attack. It doesn`t matter if it`s a martial arts move, a magical spell or your secret superweapon, if you can`t say its name, it just isn`t nearly as cool or effective. Having a special attack is always a must, but not impressive enough. Every special attack needs a name. A really awesome and outstanding name which is easy to remember and even easier and impressive to yell. Because it just is not enough to name your attack. No, to unleash the full power of your attack, you have to call its name in your most MANLY and LOUDEST voice. It does not matter whether it is a martial arts move, a magical spell or flying drills from your mecha, if you can`t call its name, it just isn`t nearly as cool or effective. Not a requirement but wearing shades while calling your attack makes it at least twice as cool, moreover giving your mecha or magical companion shades too results in an immeasurable level of awesomeness, bringing down every enemy just through the POWER OF YOUR VOICE. A standard feature of practically every mecha, mahou shoujo, high fantasy, or martial arts anime. [Source: TV Tropes]

tag.name: gunfights
tag.description: Fights where two or more parties are firing guns at one another.

tag.name: future
tag.description: Anime that fall under the future category are the ones that have a society that could have originated from ours. In most cases it should go hand to hand with sci-fi since we expect the future to consist of advanced technology, however, in the case where it`s explicitly stated in the story that the anime takes place "x years into the future", the state of technology doesn`t matter as long as it`s long into the future. The anime can be set in an alternative universe not tied with our own, as long as it has a futuristic feel to it. This category sports quite a lot of anime, mostly stemming from SciFi, but not necessarily only from there.

tag.name: space
tag.description: The final frontier.

tag.name: Earth
tag.description: The Earth is the third planet from the Sun, and the densest and fifth-largest of the eight planets in the Solar System. It is in effect a ball of hot mud, but on the surface it`s cold enough, so most of us live on it (or are supposed to). It is circa 4.5 billion years old, and, unless we humans succeed in destroying it over the next couple of centuries, it is expected to last for quite another while, though the changes in the Sun`s emissions due to its aging will likely cause the extinction of everything; the species of earthlings are guaranteed to die, even if we fail to kill them -- unless, of course, we find ourselves another planet and figure out a way to take everything there. Our little planet on a corner of this galaxy may mean nothing in the grand scheme of things, but to its inhabitants it is their home, so, as a species, we cherish it dearly, to the point many cultures even to this day deify it. Being the home to the human civilizations, the Earth is the main setting of most fiction, be it anime or otherwise, but not only are many titles set in other places, such as unrelated fantasy worlds, in a considerable number of fictional titles the Earth is actually destroyed by aggressive alien invaders.

tag.name: mecha
tag.description: Mecha in Japanese basically means mechanical things; everything from an electric whisk or a car to a spaceship or a robot. Here however we limit it to the more exotic things usually referred to as mecha anime: robots, whether controlled by a human or not, and their ilk. See Androids, Piloted Robots, Power Suits, Robot Helpers, Transforming Robots for a more specific classification.

tag.name: transforming craft
tag.description: A transforming craft is an object built by humans or other intelligent lifeforms, usually a robot but sometimes also a vehicle of some sort, that can rearrange its parts in order to switch between a minimum of two forms.

tag.name: piloted robot
tag.description: Piloted Robots are, as the name suggests, robots that cannot control themselves; they need to be steered from somewhere, this can be from a human sitting inside or a remote controlled option.

tag.name: super deformed
tag.description: A caricature style often seen in anime when the character shows extreme emotions, like fear, anger, happiness, surprise, or shame. Seen as cute, as part of humorous comedy. The character`s http://anidb.net/t4055 [face suddenly turns into a simplified version], the body will usually also deform into that of a small child (oversized head, short limbs, extra-large tears).

tag.name: slapstick
tag.description: Slapstick humour is generally recognized by lots of physical abuse, horseplay and practical jokes. Also often seen are impossible situations, using sounds to illustrate impossible stunts that aren`t shown on-screen and to create tension for audience anticipation.

tag.name: toilet humour
tag.description: Everything leads back to poo.

tag.name: nudity
tag.description: Nudity is the state of wearing no clothing. The wearing of clothing is exclusively a human characteristic. The amount of clothing worn depends on functional considerations (such as a need for warmth or protection from the elements) and social considerations. In some situations the minimum amount of clothing (i.e. covering of a person`s genitals) may be socially acceptable, while in others much more clothing is expected. Note: Refer to further guidance on http://wiki.anidb.net/w/Categories:Content_Indicators [the Wiki page] for how to apply tag weights for content indicators. People, as individuals and in groups, have varying attitudes towards their own nudity. Some people are relaxed about appearing less than fully clothed in front of others, while others are uncomfortable or inhibited in that regard. People are nude in a variety of situations, and whether they are prepared to disrobe in front of others depends on the social context in which the issue arises. For example, people need to bathe without clothing, some people also sleep in the nude, some prefer to sunbathe in the nude or at least topless, while others are nude in other situations. Some people adopt naturism as a lifestyle. Though the wearing of clothes is the social norm in most cultures, some cultures, groups and individuals are more relaxed about nudity, though attitudes often depend on context. On the other hand, some people feel uncomfortable in the presence of any nudity, and the presence of a nude person in a public place can give rise to controversy, irrespective of the attitude of the person who is nude. Besides meeting social disapproval, in some places public nudity may constitute a crime of indecent exposure. Many people have strong views on nudity, which to them can involve issues and standards of modesty, decency and morality. Some people have an psychological aversion to nudity, called gymnophobia. Many people regard nudity to be inherently sexual and erotic. Nudity is to be found in a multitude of media, including art, photography, film and on the Internet. It is a factor in adult entertainment of various types. Especially gratuitous fanservice anime shows tend to show their (usually female) characters frequently without any clothes, though often hiding genitals through the means of additions like steam. Source: wiki

tag.name: violence
tag.description: Violence is the use of physical force against oneself or another entity, compelling action against one`s will on pain of being hurt. Note: Refer to further guidance on http://wiki.anidb.net/w/Categories:Content_Indicators [the Wiki page] for how to apply tag weights for content indicators.

tag.name: sudden girlfriend appearance
tag.description: Sudden Girlfriend Appearance anime involve a sudden change in the main character`s life where (s)he suddenly gets confronted with an individual (s)he`s sexually attracted to, the two of them inevitably becoming a couple.

tag.name: plot continuity
tag.description: Consistency of the characteristics of persons, plot, objects, places and events seen by the viewer. A single linear focused plot is highly continuous. A truly random plot is highly discontinuous.

tag.name: new
tag.description: Not based on anything, the story is a new work, usually made up by the people involved in creating the anime. Generally if an original work (原作) credit is given, it will be to the studio, or director, or other members of the production team.

tag.name: furo scene
tag.description: Furo (polite: Ofuro) is Japanese for bath, specifically a type of bath which originated as a short, steep-sided wooden bathtub. Baths of this type are found all over Japan in houses, apartments and traditional Japanese inns (Ryokans). Furo are part of the Japanese ritual of bathing, not used for washing but for relaxing and warming oneself. Washing is carried out separately outside the furo, and only when completely clean does the bather enter the water. Generally Japanese bathrooms are small, so the bathroom is set up much like a walk-in shower area but containing the ofuro. The cheapest and shortest way to show naked skin on TV, at least as much as allowed. It usually only takes up few minutes at most and as such it gives the staff the opportunity to draw the characters in the nude and raise the DVD sales while still maintaining a "non-filler" episode. Compare to the big brothers http://anidb.net/t4290 [sentou episode] and http://anidb.net/t3444 [onsen episode]. See also http://anidb.net/t5846 [beach episode], and http://anidb.net/t6046 [pool episode].

tag.name: mafia
tag.description: A mafia is a type of organized crime syndicate whose primary activities are protection racketeering, the arbitration of disputes between criminals, and the organizing and oversight of illegal agreements and transactions. Secondary activities may be practiced such as gambling, drug trafficking, loan sharking, and fraud. The term was originally applied to the Sicilian mafia, but has since expanded to encompass other organizations of similar methods and purpose, such as in "the Russian mafia" or "the Japanese mafia", and is applied informally by the press and public, but the criminal organizations themselves have their own terms; for example, the original Sicilian and Italian-American mafia call themselves "cosa nostra", while the Japanese mafia calls itself "yakuza". Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: action
tag.description: Action anime usually involve a fairly straightforward story of good guys versus bad guys, where most disputes are resolved by using physical force. It often contains a lot of shooting, explosions and fighting.

tag.name: angst
tag.description: A feeling of general discomfort and uneasiness is present due to either trivial or more serious reasons, often accompanied by depression. Warning: may contain copious amounts of brooding and sighing. Etymology: "Angst" is a German word meaning fear or anxiety.

tag.name: science fiction
tag.description: Science fiction stories usually focus on how situations could be different in the future when we are more technologically advanced; due to either our own achievements or having met with other civilizations whom we have learned from.

tag.name: comedy
tag.description: Anime whose central struggle causes hilarious results. These stories are built upon funny characters, situations and events. A comedy anime is laced with humour and sets out to provoke laughter from the audience. Japanese humour can be a bit strange to westerners, so if you`re new to this type of humour, just bear with it; it`ll most likely grow on you if you`re a fan of other kinds of comedy.

tag.name: ecchi
tag.description: Fan service is found in many anime, in many forms. When the service has a distinctly sexual slant to it, and it appears to be a major focus of the show, then it`s safe to assume you`re watching ecchi. The word "ecchi" is used by English-speaking anime fans to refer to refer to soft-core pornographic or sexually suggestive anime and manga. This is a western invention; in Japanese, it is a catch-all term for all things anyhow sexual in nature, not being limited to porn, but also not really considered a "milder" term, as it may also refer to sexual intercourse itself. The term "ecchi" in Japanese comes from the pronunciation of the letter "H" in English, which is rendered into Japanese syllabary as エッチ, which in turn is transliterated in the English alphabet as "ecchi" or "etchi". It is not, as many believe, short for "hentai" -- that, too, seems to be a western invention. It is, however, nearly as misunderstood and misapplied a term as "hentai". The line between ecchi and hentai, from the western perspective over these terms, can be hard to draw at times; one good rule of thumb is: if it was aired on Japanese public TV at all, it probably wasn`t hentai. Ecchi usually features all the specifics to human anatomy that can only be found in anime, and generally avoids full nudity, instead abusing of panty shots. Hentai, on the other hand, will usually show full frontal nudity in some explicit form, including genitalia, and full, intimate sex scenes. At its mildest, ecchi is composed of double entendres, big misunderstandings, and sexual farce; at its most explicit, it is still in the realm of softcore pornography, with full breast shots, full back nudity and similar content, but no display of genitalia. Another good way to distinguish the two is looking for animated sex scenes; if one is found, you have generally left the genre entirely, though a few borderline exceptions apply here. For AniDB`s purposes, the distinction between explicit ecchi and actual hentai is simple: if it was sold with a 18+ restriction in its country of origin, it is hentai; if it was sold without it, it is ecchi. Source: TV Tropes

tag.name: romance
tag.description: Romance describes a story that deals with love between two or more characters typically also having an optimistic ending. Romance is also a difficulty encountered when creating a harem.

tag.name: friendship
tag.description: The feeling of trust, kindness, and friendship between a group of high school students for example, is a central theme of this anime.

tag.name: politics
tag.description: From commies to fat capitalist pigs, all the stuff done by the "guys with the power", mainly evil tactics for gaining more power over the masses. Watching this title may remind you why CNN is boring.

tag.name: school life
tag.description: Since a large part of the anime audience still takes part in school life or is visiting college, it is only natural to choose a setting the audience can identify with, be it elementary, middle, or high school. For the older viewers a college setting with more mature real-life problems is appropriate. And since clubs take up so much time in the lives of students, these are obviously also important.

tag.name: anti-war
tag.description: The anime portrays the insanity of war.

tag.name: crime
tag.description: The underworld we talk about here is not to be confused with the place where people are believed to go after they die, but the general term for organized crime. It is a shady world, unknown to most people, where illegal things like murder, smuggling, drug dealing and similar are happening daily. Groups known to be acting in this world are for example the mafia or the yakuza.

tag.name: disaster
tag.description: A disaster is a large-scale situation that causes great loss of or damage or threat to life, health, property, society, or the environment, irrespective of its source or cause. Disasters have substantial, long-lasting negative repercussions, and great effort must be spent in order to undo or mitigate their effects.

tag.name: religion
tag.description: Religion is a collection of belief systems, cultural systems, and worldviews that relate humanity to spirituality and, sometimes, to moral values. Many religions have narratives, symbols, traditions and sacred histories that are intended to give meaning to life or to explain the origin of life or the universe. They tend to derive morality, ethics, religious laws or a preferred lifestyle from their ideas about the cosmos and human nature.

tag.name: revenge
tag.description: A primary factor that drives the plot forward, is the almost obsessive desire of one of the characters to get back at someone else.

tag.name: conspiracy
tag.description: The conspiracy thriller (or paranoid thriller) is a sub-genre of the thriller which flourished in the 1970s in the US (and was echoed in other parts of the world) in the wake of a number of high-profile scandals and controversies (most notably Vietnam, the assassination of President Kennedy, Chappaquiddick and Watergate), and which exposed what many people regarded as the clandestine machinations and conspiracies beneath the orderly fabric of political life. The protagonists of conspiracy thrillers are often journalists or amateur investigators who find themselves (often inadvertently) pulling on a small thread which unravels a vast conspiracy that ultimately goes "all the way to the top".

tag.name: alcohol
tag.description: Alcohol (or more scientifically, ethanol), is one of the world`s oldest psychoactive substances. It is traditionally found in the form of a beverage such as beer, wine, or liquor, although in some contexts it can be inhaled to produce similar or intoxication, and some people prefer another way of consuming beverage-form alcohol. Alcoholic beverages are many and varied, due to production methods (fermentation or distillation), source materials (grains, fruits, vegetables, other plants), added substances such as flavorings, and many more ways of defining different forms of alcoholic beverages. Alcoholic beverages are divided into three general classes: beers, wines, and spirits. They are legally consumed in most countries, and over 100 countries have laws regulating their production, sale, and consumption. In particular, such laws specify the minimum age at which a person may legally buy or drink them. This minimum age varies between 16 and 25 years, depending upon the country and the type of drink. Most nations set it at 18 years of age.

tag.name: the arts
tag.description: The arts represent an outlet of human expression, usually influenced by culture, and driven by human creative impulse. Major constituents of the arts include literature – including poetry, novels and short stories, and epics; performing arts – among them music, dance, and theatre; culinary arts such as baking, chocolatiering, and winemaking; media arts like photography and film, and visual arts – including drawing, painting, and sculpting. Some art forms combine a visual element with performance (e.g. film) and the written word (e.g. comics). From prehistoric cave paintings to modern day films, art serves as a vessel for storytelling and conveying mankind`s relationship with its environment. Source: Wiki

tag.name: psychoactive drugs
tag.description: Psychoactive drugs are chemical substances that affect the function of the central nervous system, altering perception, mood or consciousness. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: New Year`s Day
tag.description: It is tradition in Japan to celebrate the new year at a Shinto shrine (hatsumode). The protagonists will offer some money, ring a bell at the end of a thick rope, and then pray for good fortune. This usually goes along with gorging yourself at the many temporary food stalls, playing various games, and drawing a fortune. The female characters in the anime will usually dress up in a kimono, to show off their traditional Japanese clothing, while watching the fireworks.

tag.name: tragedy
tag.description: Tragedy is a form of drama characterized by seriousness and dignity, usually involving a conflict between a character and some higher power, such as the law, the gods, fate, or society.

tag.name: coming of age
tag.description: In the strict sense the Coming of age describes a young person`s transition from adolescence to adulthood. In anime the term is used in a more general sense where the protagonists have to face a challenge, make an important decision in their life, take on responsibility, or learn a lesson, and by overcoming these obstacles they reach a higher level of maturity.

tag.name: post-apocalyptic
tag.description: An anime that takes place on future Earth (or it could be an alternative universe) after a major cataclysm has occurred. World War III, an alien invasion, plague, global warming or some other general disaster are common themes to build a post-apocalyptic world upon, where the effects were severe enough that mankind barely survived. The time frame may be immediately after the catastrophe, focusing on the travails or psychology of survivors, or considerably later, often including the theme that the existence of pre-catastrophe civilization has been forgotten (or mythologised). Post-apocalyptic stories often take place in an agrarian, non-technological future world, or a world where only scattered elements of technology remain. There is a considerable degree of blurring between post-apocalyptic fiction and that which deals with false utopias or dystopian societies.

tag.name: war
tag.description: War is a phenomenon of organized violent conflict, typified by extreme aggression, societal disruption and adaptation, and high mortality. The objective of warfare differs in accord with a group`s role in a conflict: The goals of offensive warfare are typically the submission, assimilation or destruction of another group, while the goals of defensive warfare are simply the repulsion of the offensive force and, often, survival itself. Relative to each other, combatants in warfare are called enemies. The terms military, militant, and militarism each refer to fundamental aspects of war, i.e. the organized group, the combative individual, and the supportive ethos (respectively). Source: wiki

tag.name: post-war
tag.description: An armed conflict has ended not too long ago, devastation of the world or society is still evident.

tag.name: unsorted
tag.description: a bunch of tags that still need to be either deleted or moved into proper places.

tag.name: nervous breakdown
tag.description: A character sees his entire world being destroyed around him, and his brain can`t take it anymore.

tag.name: parricide
tag.description: Parricide, or the murder of family members, is the act of taking the life of of one or more of one`s own close family members, or even one`s entire family; that may include spouses, parents, grandparents, children, grandchildren, siblings, cousins, uncles, aunts, nephews, and nieces, among others.

tag.name: important haircut
tag.description: When a character cuts off his or her hair, it often symbolizes a rite of passage or bout of character growth. A princess striking out on an adventure, or a new recruit at boot camp, for instance. Hair is something that takes time and effort to grow, so parting with it voluntarily can be a powerful act. This is particularly a big deal when women get haircuts. Yet in fiction, even an accidental hair slicing can leave a character with a surprisingly even cut. In many religions (Western Christianity, Ancient Egyptian religion, and others) priests and/or monks cut/shave their hair. Roman Catholic nuns also tend to cut and mantain their hair short under their veils when they enter the nunneries. The cutting of one`s own hair is also a part of Buddhist mythology, specifically something done by Siddhartha himself early on in his path to enlightenment, so anime examples might draw from this as an allusion. There are also some cultures, including Native American and many Asians, where a person would cut his or her hair as an act of grief, disgrace, or even rebellion. In the Confucian tradition, hair (like the rest of your body) is considered a gift from your parents and may not be damaged without a very good reason. Furthermore, prisoners and psychiatric patients commonly have their heads shaved, often to prevent the spread of lice, but sometimes also as a demeaning measure. Source: TVTRope

tag.name: genocide
tag.description: The systematic killing of substantial numbers of people on the basis of ethnicity, religion, political opinion, social status, or other particularity. Acts committed with intent to destroy, in whole or in part, a national, ethnic, racial or religious group.

tag.name: bendy lasers
tag.description: Lasers — of all things — bend at strange angles, are profusely in effect in this anime. Usually seen in a space setting, as part of a weapon system on spaceships.

tag.name: environmentalism
tag.description: Environmental protection is a practice of protecting the natural environment on individual, organizational or governmental levels, for the benefit of both the natural environment and humans. Due to the pressures of population and technology, the biophysical environment is being degraded, sometimes permanently. This has been recognized, and governments have begun placing restraints on activities that cause environmental degradation. Since the 1960s, activity of environmental movements has created awareness of the various environmental issues. (Source: Wikipedia)

tag.name: human experimentation
tag.description: Genetic, biological, chemical or psychological experimentation on human beings are portrayed or their aftermath is shown.

tag.name: space elevator
tag.description: A needle-like structure placed on the equator of a planet connecting the surface with a low planetary orbit in about 200-300km height (it may even reach out into a geostationary orbit). Very efficient way to move mass "out of" a planet`s gravity well — much more efficient than e.g. chemical rockets. Alas it is not yet possible to build a space elevator, because all know materials would be crushed under their own weight. There is a faint hope that carbon-based nano-tubes may be a usable material in the future though.

tag.name: biopunk
tag.description: Biopunk stories explore the struggles of individuals or groups, often the product of human experimentation, against a backdrop of totalitarian governments or mega-corporations which misuse biotech as means of social control or capitalist extortion. Unlike cyberpunk, biopunk does not centre on information technology but on synthetic biology.

tag.name: damsel in distress
tag.description: The damsel in distress is usually a young, nubile woman placed in a dire predicament by a villain or a monster and requires a hero to dash to her rescue. Often used to unite the cast of a show for this one goal, to make them put differences aside and become a band of nakama. Examples: Sakoshita Yanagi from Rekka no Honoo, Yuuki Miaka from Fushigi Yuugi or Higurashi Kagome from Inuyasha.

tag.name: remastered version available
tag.description: This anime has been remastered in a higher quality format than the original release. The remaster may be a simple upscale, or it could be a full enhancement project from the original frames. This is irrespective of whether specific groups have released rips of such formats to the internet.

tag.name: kids in war
tag.description: When minors participate in armed conflict.

tag.name: Bright slap
tag.description: "You hit me! Not even my father ever hit me!" You are the commander of a spaceship, leader of a faction or a team and your best mecha pilot stops fighting and grows increasingly hysterical and angsty, while the enemy could strike you at any time. What are you going to do? You slap or punch him, preferably in the face, and back to his senses while delivering a heroic speech that would turn any wimp into a man of destiny. Named after Bright Noa of Mobile Suit Gundam, a prominent user of this for-sure method.

tag.name: sociocultural evolution
tag.description: Describes how cultures and societies develop over time, based on both cultural evolution and social evolution. A post-apocalyptic or a Utopian setting would show very interesting changes in human behaviour, mental state, or simply daily life.

tag.name: coup d`etat
tag.description: A coup d`état (/ˌkuːdeɪˈtɑː/; French: blow of state; plural: coups d`état), also known as a coup, a putsch, or an overthrow, is the sudden and illegal seizure of a government, usually instigated by a small group of the existing state establishment to depose the established government and replace it with a new ruling body. A coup d`état is considered successful when the usurpers establish their dominance. If a coup fails, a civil war may ensue.

tag.name: organic mecha
tag.description: An organic mecha is a mecha that has organic tissue in its composition. The most prominent historical example is http://anidb.net/a22 [Neon Genesis Evangelion].

tag.name: evil military
tag.description: The military is depicted as being of a nefarious nature in this anime. Be it through the heartlessness that their soldiers convey, or the ruthless killing of innocents, the military in this anime is not to be messed with.

tag.name: gore
tag.description: A Splatter film or Gore film is a sub-genre of horror film that deliberately focuses on graphic portrayals of gore and graphic violence. These films, through the use of special effects and excessive blood and guts, tend to display an overt interest in the vulnerability of the human body and the theatricality of its mutilation. Due to their willingness to portray images society might consider shocking, splatter films share some ideological grounds with the transgressive art movement. The term "splatter cinema" was coined by George A. Romero to describe his film Dawn of the Dead, though Dawn of the Dead is generally considered by critics to have higher aspirations, such as social commentary, than to be simply exploitative for its own sake. [Source: wiki]

tag.name: cultural references
tag.description: The plot of this anime shows signs of cultural references, these are often jokes that make reference to a certain custom, habit or history that is specifically attributed to that culture. Knowledge of the culture itself is needed in order to properly understand these jokes.

tag.name: contraband
tag.description: The anime includes depiction of smuggling or smuggled goods.

tag.name: rebellion
tag.description:
Rebellion, uprising, or insurrection is a refusal of obedience or order. It may, therefore, be seen as encompassing a range of behaviors aimed at destroying or taking over the position of an established authority such as a government, governor, president, political leader, financial institution, or person in charge. On the one hand the forms of behaviour can include non-violent methods such as the (overlapping but not quite identical) phenomena of civil disobedience, civil resistance and nonviolent resistance. On the other hand it may encompass violent campaigns. Those who participate in rebellions, especially if they are armed rebellions, are known as "rebels".
Source: Wiki

tag.name: daikaijuu
tag.description: Literally translating to giant monster, daikaiju is an element found often in Japanese entertainment. Although usually for the science fiction genre it is also often used in horror, fantasy, mecha, and to a lesser extent comedy. Any monster that towers over a house technically qualifies as a daikaiju. Some anime, usually mecha, will go as far as calling their daikaiju with a specific title.

tag.name: murder
tag.description: To murder means to bring about someone else`s death, by a voluntary act. Whether it comes from the killer`s own hand or by exposing the victim to life-threatening circumstances, the result is foreseeable and sought by the perpetrator. Someone who murders as their profession/job is an http://anidb.net/t2399 [assassin or hitman].

tag.name: suicide
tag.description: One or several characters in this anime commit suicide.

tag.name: love at first sight
tag.description: Plot device: When two characters meet for the first time, at least one party, supposedly, immediately falls in love with the other party, and from then on tries to get to know that party better.

tag.name: boy meets girl
tag.description: A classical type of plot in story writing, where the story begins with a boy meeting a girl leading to romantic development between the two. More often than not the boy loses the girl later on and has to find her again.

tag.name: happy ending
tag.description: And they lived "happily ever after"... *sniff*. All issues in the anime have been resolved, the love polygons sorted out, the conflicts resolved, the guy gets the girl (or the other way around), and everyone else lives on blissfully. (Not very realistic, but then again this is anime.)

tag.name: protection complex
tag.description: A character has a protection complex if the character is overly protective of other characters, beyond what would be considered a "normal" or "expected" duty of care. The magnitude of overprotection can vary. It can be as low as constantly nagging someone to "stay safe". It can be as extreme as the protector making it their mission in life to protect the other character.

tag.name: war-zone realities
tag.description: War is hell. This tag is for when characters experience the hell of war... not just the exciting stuff blowing up part.

tag.name: nature strikes back
tag.description: Humanity continues to pollute and waste the land. Until at some point (usually in the future), nature "has had it" and devises a way to countermand this dire situation. This cleansing of the Earth may well take out humanity, though.

tag.name: tone changes
tag.description: The anime switches quickly, often rather drastically between different moods or tones, sometimes even on the same scene.

tag.name: propaganda
tag.description: Propaganda is communication aimed at influencing the attitude of a community toward some cause or position. As opposed to impartially providing information, propaganda in its most basic sense, presents information primarily to influence an audience. Propaganda often presents facts selectively (thus lying by omission) to encourage a particular synthesis, or uses loaded messages to produce an emotional rather than rational response to the information presented. The desired result is a change of the attitude toward the subject in the target audience to further a political agenda.

tag.name: paramilitary
tag.description: A paramilitary is a semi-militarized force whose organizational structure, training, subculture, and (often) function are similar to those of a professional military, and which is not included as part of a state`s formal armed forces. Though a paramilitary is not a military force, it is usually equivalent to a military`s light infantry force in terms of intensity, firepower and organizational structure. A paramilitary may also commonly fall under the command of a military, even despite not being part of the military or play an assisting role for the military in times of war. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: Itano circus
tag.description: The Itano circus is named after Itano Ichirou, a Japanese animator, and refers to a highly stylized and acrobatic method of depicting aerial combat and dogfights in many anime, particularly the Macross series, where it was utilised by Itano for the first time and was ground-breaking. The Itano circus is characterized by detailed, fluid shading of the mecha, the close-range acrobatic moves the duelling fighters make in combat, as well as twisting contrails left by fighters and missiles. It is also commonly used in specific reference to an attack where a mecha or spaceship launches a large swarm of missiles with meticulously animated spiralling smoke trails and erratic trajectories.

tag.name: massacre
tag.description: Mass murder.

tag.name: rivalry
tag.description: Quite broadly used term describing a conflict, contest, struggle, or opposition of some sort. Typical examples: The mostly comedic rivalry for the love of a protagonist in a harem anime (love polygon), the more "mindless" battles between wannabe delinquents in a school fighting anime, or the struggle between good & evil in an epic conflict for world domination.

tag.name: jealousy
tag.description: A character is jealous of another character either due to love, or power, or wealth.

tag.name: organ trafficking
tag.description: Illegal trafficking of human organs.

tag.name: call my name
tag.description: "TETSUOOOOOO!!" "KANEDAAAAAA!!" "TAMAHOMEEEE!!" "MIAKAAAA!!" Feelings of any kind towards other characters are best shown by calling each other`s name, loud, REALLY LOUD. For better effect at least twice or thrice. For lover`s couples and mortal enemies it is a requirement to run towards each other while calling each other`s name, unaware of the surroundings.

tag.name: broken friendship
tag.description: For a broken friendship a group of three friends is a must, the break up can be caused by betrayal or death, a love triangle is also possible. The ghost of the old friendship will be the cause of many flashbacks and reminiscences. A dreaded face to face could be a major event or just used as plot device.

tag.name: kamikaze
tag.description: Literally means "divine wind" or "god`s wind" in Japanese. A suicide attacker, specifically the WWII Japanese pilots, that flew their planes into Allied ships and other targets.

tag.name: human - non-human relationship
tag.description: The relationship between a human and a non-human — be it alien, or artificial — is explored in this anime. This usually means between a male human and a female (humanoid) alien or AI (avatar).

tag.name: human sacrifice
tag.description: Human sacrifice is the act of killing one or more human beings as part of a ritual. Throughout the majority of human history, primitive societies have engaged in human sacrifice, generally as a religious act, such as an offering to please or appease deities, spirits, or the deceased. Other uses that have been seen include magic rituals, usually related to black magic or the summoning of demons.

tag.name: the power of love
tag.description: The power of love is not only the strongest power known to mankind, it is the strongest power in the universe. The power of love conquers all things. It makes people cry, it makes people laugh, it can make them sing and occasionally it even brings dead people back to life, just so. More so than the power of friendship, the power of true love gives boundless strength and resolution; by the power of love every hardship can be overcome, every issue can be resolved and it does make people resistant to food poisoning (caused by the bad cooking of their loved ones). Even the big bad evil doesn`t stand a chance against the power of true love and often ends up redeemed. Even when the power of love is not literally and directly responsible, the scene is often set so that the audience is left with the impression that it was "really responsible".

tag.name: TO BE MOVED TO EPISODE
tag.description: Tags under this parent tag are going to be moved to episode tags and removed from the anime they`re currently assigned to. They will be blocked from the anime system once that move is complete. Please help with that job if you know what episodes they should be assigned to.

tag.name: TO BE MOVED TO CHARACTER
tag.description: Tags under this parent tag are going to be moved to character tags and removed from the anime they`re currently assigned to. They will be blocked from the anime system once that move is complete. Please help with that job if you know what characters they should be assigned to.

tag.name: technical aspects
tag.description: It may sometimes be useful to know about technical aspects of a show, such as information about its broadcasting or censorship. Such information can be found here.

tag.name: multi-anime projects
tag.description: Many anime are created as part of larger projects encompassing many shows without direct relation to one another. Normally, there is a specific idea in mind: for example, the http://anidb.net/t4859 [Young Animator Training Project] aims to stimulate the on-the-job training of next-generation professionals of the anime industry, whereas the http://anidb.net/t3763 [World Masterpiece Theatre] aims to animate classical stories from all over the world.

tag.name: tropes
tag.description: A trope is a commonly recurring literary and rhetorical devices, motifs or clichés in creative works. This use is a broader redefining of a literary trope, the use of figurative language, via word, phrase, or even an image, for artistic effect, such as using a figure of speech. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: death
tag.description: Death is the state of no longer being alive or the process of ceasing to be alive.

tag.name: ending
tag.description: This is a container tag to house meta-like tags relating to how endings of anime play out.

tag.name: terrorism
tag.description: Terrorism is, in the broadest sense, the use of intentionally indiscriminate violence as a means to create terror among masses of people; or fear to achieve a religious or political aim. It is used in this regard primarily to refer to violence during peacetime or in war against non-combatants (mostly civilians and neutral military personnel). Some definitions now include acts of unlawful violence and war. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: speculative fiction
tag.description: Speculative fiction is an umbrella genre encompassing fiction with certain elements that do not exist in the real world, often in the context of supernatural, futuristic or other imaginative themes. This includes, but is not limited to, science fiction, fantasy, superhero fiction, horror, utopian and dystopian fiction, fairytale fantasy, supernatural fiction, as well as combinations thereof. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: Super Robot Wars
tag.description: Super Robot Wars is a series of tactical role-playing video games produced by Banpresto. The main feature of the franchise is having a story that crosses over several popular mecha anime, manga and video games, allowing characters and mecha from different titles to team up or battle one another. Due to the nature of crossover games and licensing involved, only a few games have been released outside Japan, and in English; early English-language games only feature Banpresto`s original characters and mecha, and a flagship installment were to never be released until 2016, with the English release of Super Robot Wars V in Southeast Asian countries. The franchise celebrated its 25th anniversary in 2016. Source: Wikipedia

character.name: Renton Thurston
character.description: Renton Thurston is the main protagonist of the Eureka Seven series. He is referred to in episode previews simply as "the boy". Renton thinks his life is mundane and dreams of doing the extraordinary. At the beginning of the series, he becomes a member of http://anidb.net/ch2961 [Gekkostate] in order to be near his idol, http://anidb.net/ch2900 [Holland], and his love at first sight, http://anidb.net/ch2875 [Eureka]. In seasons one and two, the other crew members generally see Renton as Gekkostate`s "busboy", doing chores such as cooking and cleaning. He occasionally rides with Eureka in the http://anidb.net/ch2958 [Nirvash typeZERO] and is able to lift. In the third season, Renton is shown to mature a bit. Eureka and Renton continue to pilot the typeZERO, and his relationship with Eureka deepens, though the kids (http://anidb.net/ch2895 [Maurice], http://anidb.net/ch2896 [Maeter], and http://anidb.net/ch2897 [Linck]) still refuse to regard Renton as their "papa". In season four Renton matures even further, coming into his own as a father to the kids and a prominent member of Gekkostate.

character.name: Ageha Swallowtails
character.description: The Ageha-tai consists of 5 specially trained orphans acting as a anti-Coralian unit.

episode.title: ブルーマンデー
Blue Monday
Blue Monday
Blue Monday
Niebieski poniedziałek
Blue Monday
episode.summary: Renton Thurston leads a boring life for a fourteen-year-old boy, but that changes when his compact drive starts to glow with the word “Eureka” and a strange, beautiful girl crashes a mecha into his home. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ブルー・スカイ・フィッシュ
Blue Sky Fish
Blue Sky Fish
Niebiańskie rybki
Blue Sky Fish
episode.summary: While Renton tries to get the Amita Drive to Eureka and the Nirvash, he finds a new sense of determination. Once he finds Eureka emotions flair, the military attacks, and a strange power is unleashed. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: モーション・ブルー
Motion Blue
Motion Blue
Smutek
Motion Blue
episode.summary: As tensions mount between the military and Gekkostate at the airport, Eureka teaches Renton how to detect Trapar particle waves. If the Gekko is going to escape the military blockade, the two of them are going to have to pull off a daring maneuver. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ウォーターメロン
Watermelon
Watermelon
Arbuz
Watermelon
episode.summary: The Council of Sages discusses the Nirvash’s immense display of power and how it is connected to Adrock Thurston—Renten’s father. Meanwhile, Renton joins Gekkostate to get closer to Eureka, only to find himself at the bottom of the organization. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ビビット・ビット
Vivid Bit
Vivid bit
Vivid bit
Vivid Bit
episode.summary: When a shopping trip with fellow Gekkostate members Talho and Hilda turns ugly, it’s up to Renton to pilot an LFO solo for the first time in order to keep everyone from getting into too much trouble. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: チャイルドフッド
Childhood
Childhood
Dzieciństwo
Childhood
episode.summary: Eureka’s “kids” pull a series of pranks on Renton, dead-set on keeping anyone from getting too close to the woman they call “Mama.” Meanwhile, Renton goes out on a dangerous mission without authorization from the rest of Gekkostate. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: アブソリュート・デフィート
Absolute Defeat
Absolute defeat
Całkowita porażka
Absolute Defeat
episode.summary: Renton gets sent on an important Gekkostate mission to deliver a dangerous package—but there’s something strange about the errand. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: グロリアス・ブリリアンス
Glorious Brilliance
Glorious brilliance
Oślepiający błysk
Glorious Brilliance
episode.summary: On a shopping trip, Eureka, Renton, and a few others run into a woman named Tiptory. But when Holland appears and interrupts their meeting, it’s revealed that there’s more to Tiptory than meets the eye. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ペーパームーン・シャイン
Paper Moon Shine
Paper moon shine
W blasku papierowego księżyca
Paper Moon-Shine
episode.summary: The Gekko lands in the ruins of Ciudades Del Cielo, where Renton tries to cut loose by lifting—much to Holland’s annoyance. When Renton disappears into the city, he discovers the secret behind Gekkostate’s formation. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ハイアー・ザン・ザ・サン
Higher Than the Sun
Higher Than the Sun
Wyżej niż słońce
Higher Than the Sun
episode.summary: A huge Trapar wave is unleashed and Holland decides he and the others need to have a little fun lifting. When they end up at military base, though, Holland and Talho recall painful memories. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: イントゥー・ザ・ネイチャー
Into the Nature
Into the nature
W głąb natury
Into the Nature
episode.summary: Gekkostate investigates a strange sphere that appeared in the sky. Eureka helps out, despite her declining health, and a new Nirvash shows up—typeTheEND. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: アクペリエンス・1
Acperience 1
Acperience 1
Doświadczenie 1
Acperience 1
episode.summary: The typeTheEND and typeZERO go head to head as the Gekko and the Izumo play a game of chicken. Inside the Coralian, Renton, Eureka, and Anemone share a common dream—that may turn out to be a nightmare. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ザ・ビギニング
The Beginning
The beginning
Rozpoczęcie
The Beginning
episode.summary: The Coralian has disappeared, but more questions about the connection between Anemone, Eureka, and Renton are raised when they meet face to face, leading to a medicine-collecting side mission in a nearby town. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: メモリー・バンド
Memory Band
Memory band
Opaska pamięci
Memory Band
episode.summary: The Gekko has been seriously damaged from its battle with the military, and its crewmembers reflect on the recent events. Stoner offers up his own speculations as to what everything means—and why Eureka was so affected by the Coralian. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ヒューマン・ビヘイヴュア
Human Behaviour
Human behaviour
Zachowanie człowieka
Human Behaviour
episode.summary: Renton visits the town he grew up in and shows Eureka some of his important memories. Their mission is to collect a special fruit, but when Renton runs into people from his past, things take an unexpected turn. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: オポジット・ヴュー
Opposite View
Opposite view
Inny punkt widzenia
Opposite View
episode.summary: The Gekko lands in an abandoned mine in order to complete repairs. After a frustrating conversation with Eureka, Renton heads out to explore and stumbles upon a strange building in the mine tunnels. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: スカイ・ロック・ゲート
Sky Rock Gate
Sky rock gate
Brama Niebiańskiej Skały
Sky Rock Gate
episode.summary: If the Gekko is going to be repaired, it’s going to need a whole lot of reflection tape. Luckily, there’s a craftsman nearby who can make it, but only if Renton and the others can gather enough skyfish for raw materials. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: イル コミュニケーション
Ill Communication
Ill communication
Zła komunikacja
Ill Communication
episode.summary: A miner still working in the abandoned tunnels where the Gekko is being repaired befriends members of the crew. But the old man’s intentions are called into question when he discovers the typeZero Nirvash. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: アクペリエンス・2
Acperience 2
Acperience 2
Wydarzenie 2
Acperience 2
episode.summary: Eureka’s health and spirits are fading—possibly because of the mines—which lead her to take brash action, endangering herself and others. Meanwhile, an enemy ship heads toward the Gekko, intent on taking the ship and its crew any way they can. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: サブスタンス アビューズ
Substance Abuse
Substance abuse
Agresja
Substance Abuse
episode.summary: Eureka has merged with a scub, sending many of the crew into a panic. At the same time, Holland responds to a distress call and goes on a dangerous mission to rescue a Vodarac high priest. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ランナウェイ
Runaway
Runaway
Ucieczka
Runaway
episode.summary: The Vodarac priest that Holland rescued manages to remove the scub from Eureka’s body, but the ordeal won’t be without scars. Meanwhile, Renton tries to come to terms with the death and destruction he’s caused since joining Gekkostate. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: クラックポット
Crackpot
Crackpot
Dziwak
Crackpot
episode.summary: The Gekko crew tries to figure out the best way to tell Eureka that Renton has gone. Renton comes across Charles and Ray Beams and their carrier ship, the Swan, and decides to join them. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ディファレンシア
Differentia
Differentia
Różnica
Differentia
episode.summary: On his first mission with the Beams, Renton is faced with a difficult decision concerning the fate of a Vodarac girl. On the Gekko, Holland tries to avoid talking to Eureka about Renton, but he won’t be able to avoid the subject forever. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: パラダイス ロスト
Paradise Lost
Paradise lost
Utracony raj
Paradise Lost
episode.summary: Holland considers his previous treatment of Renton as a lonely Eureka takes on the missing boy’s duties. Meanwhile, on the Swan, the Beams’ true mission comes to light, much to Renton’s shock. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ワールズ・エンド・ガーデン
World`s End Garden
World`s end garden
Ogród z końca świata
World`s End Garden
episode.summary: Alone and wandering, Renton wears himself out searching for the Gekko. He’s taken in by a hermit and his sick wife, who have much to teach him about love and loyalty. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: モーニング・グローリー
Morning Glory
Morning glory
Poranna chwała
Morning Glory
episode.summary: Holland’s quest to find Renton hits a snag when the Gekko runs into a military fleet preparing to take on the ship. Unable to wait, Eureka leaves to search for him on her own—but Renton might be closer than she thinks. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ヘルタースケルター
Helter Skelter
Helter skelter
Helter Skelter
Helter Skelter
episode.summary: Eureka and Renton find themselves locked in the brig together, along with Eureka’s “kids.” Their reunion is cut short when Charles and Ray Beams begin their assault on the Gekko. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: メメントモリ
Memento Mori
Memento mori
Memento mori
Memento Mori
episode.summary: A death in the battle between the Swan and the Gekko has major psychological consequences for members of both crews. Meanwhile, Holland reveals to Renton that he has a past connection to the Beams. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: キープ・オン・ムービン
Keep on Movin`
Keep on movin`
Nie poddawaj się
Keep on Movin`
episode.summary: Lieutenant Dominic visits Bellforest and ends up spending a lot of time with the Thurstons. On the Gekko, a shocking revelation about Eureka’s origins takes everyone by surprise. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: チェンジ・オブ・ライフ
Change of Life
Change of life
Zmiana stylu życia
Change of Life
episode.summary: More information about the history of Euruka and the typeZERO—and Renton’s grandfather—is revealed as the Nirvash is taken for repairs at the research center where it was built. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: アニマル・アタック
Animal Attack
Animal attack
Zwierzęcy atak
Animal Attack
episode.summary: Repairs on the Nirvash continue as Dr. Eagan, a renowned researcher, has an idea as to why the machine has been acting strangely. Elsewhere, one of the Sages and Colonel Dewey discuss the future of the Coralians. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: スタート・イット・アップ
Start It Up
Start it up
Nowy początek
Start It Up
episode.summary: Renton’s grandfather is put in charge of upgrades for the Nirvash. Improvements can’t come soon enough, as an attack on the Coralians results in an all-out battle and the deployment of typeTheEND. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: パシフィック・ステイト
Pacific State
Pacific state
Nad Pacyfikiem
Pacific State
episode.summary: The Gekko lands amid the city ruins left by the Coralian attack. As Renton tries desperately to figure out a way to cheer Eureka up, Holland and Talho have an important conversation that affects the entire future of Gekkostate. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: インナー・フライト
Inner Flight
Inner flight
Walka wewnętrzna
Inner Flight
episode.summary: Holland reveals the truth about who Norb is and how he is connected to Eureka, Talho makes a shocking announcement, and Colonel Dewey and Norb discuss the future of the planet in the capital. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: アストラル・アパッチ
Astral Apache
Astral apache
Gwiezdny atak
Astral Apache
episode.summary: Gekkostate attacks the capital in order to rescue Norb, but Eureka’s unwillingness to take any more lives hinders the operation. Colonel Dewey is quick to dismiss the assault, not knowing that Holland has succeeded in finding Eureka a partner. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ファンタジア
Fantasia
Fantasia
Fantazja
Fantasia
episode.summary: Newly rescued Norb insists on returning to the Vodarac homeland, Eureka worries about improving her physical appearance, and Holland tells Renton about his first love—someone Renton knows all too well. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: レイズ・ユア・ハンド
Raise Your Hand
Raise your hand
Podnieś rękę
Raise Your Hand
episode.summary: Norb and Dr. Bear discuss the “Limit of Questions” theory, pitting science against religion. Meanwhile, Dewey makes a very public announcement about his plans for the future, which tie back to Renton’s father. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: デイト・オブ・バース
Date of Birth
Date of birth
Narodziny
Date of Birth
episode.summary: A misunderstanding between Renton and Eureka leads to awkwardness for the rest of the Gekko’s crew. Meanwhile, Dewey continues his crusade against the Sage Council, and Stoner tries to improve public perception of Gekkostate through Ray=Out. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ジョイン ザ フューチャー
Join the Future
Join the future
W przyszłość
Join the Future
episode.summary: At Norb’s insistence, Gekkostate plays a game of soccer against a professional team. In the capital, Dewey blames two high-profile deaths on the Coralians and prepares to destroy them in return. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: コズミック トリガー
Cosmic Trigger
Cosmic trigger
Kosmiczny tygrys
Cosmic Trigger
episode.summary: The Gekko arrives at the Vodarac Shrine near the Great Wall, and Norb sends Renton and Eureka inside to meet with Sakuya. Elsewhere, Dewey prepares his attack squad, which includes Anemone and a new ship, the Ginga. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 緊急特番 ナビゲーション "ray=out"
Navigation ray=out
Kinkyuu Tokuban Navigation "ray=out"
アクペリエンス・3
Acperience 3
Acperience 3
Przygoda numer 3
Acperience 3
episode.summary: Eureka enters in a strange place within the Vodarac shrine, where she learns the history of Sakuya and Norb. Outside the shrine, Holland and the rest of Gekkostate fight a military attack. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: スターダンサー
Star Dancer
Star dancer
Gwiezdny tancerz
Star Dancer
episode.summary: Holland and Gekkostate continue to defend the shrine and provide cover while Renton and Eureka head for the Great Wall in the typeZERO—but to succeed, the Nirvash is going to have to avoid military ships, Coralians, and Anemone. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ザ サンシャイン アンダーグラウンド
The Sunshine Underground
The sunshine underground
Słońce pod ziemią
The Sunshine Underground
episode.summary: Eureka, Renton, and the kids finally make it to Earth, but have no idea what to do once they’re there. Meanwhile Dewey takes Anemone to a celebration and tells her about his childhood and past with Holland. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: イッツ・オール・イン・ザ・マインド
It`s All in the Mind
It`s all in the mind
Wszystko jest w umyśle
It`s All in the Mind
episode.summary: In Warsaw, Dominic visits a facility where young girls are being experimented on with tragic consequences. On Earth, the group is not faring well, and something odd is happening to Eureka. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ドント・ユー・ウォント・ミー?
Don`t You Want Me?
Don`t you want me?
Nie chcesz mnie?
Don`t You Want Me?
episode.summary: Jurgens and Dominic board the Gekko and confront Dr. Bear. After learning the truth about the Scub Corals, they begin to question their allegiances. On Earth, stress builds between Renton and the kids regarding Eureka’s transformation. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: プラネット・ロック
Planet Rock
Planet rock
Skała planety
Planet Rock
episode.summary: When Dewey finally discovers the Scub Control Cluster, military forces launch across the world and Holland readies his crew for battle. Eureka and the kids on earth treat Renton’s fever, and the couple has a touching moment. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: アクペリエンス・4
Acperience 4
Acperience 4
Przygoda 4
Acperience 4
episode.summary: After entering the Scub Control Cluster, Renton is reunited with his sister and learns how the Coralian came to be. It seems as though the fate of everything depends on what actions he decides to take. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: バレエ・メカニック
Ballet Mecanique
Ballet mecanique
Mechaniczny balet
Ballet Mechanic
episode.summary: Dewey is able to create a hole in the Scub Coral that Anemone can slip through. Will Dominic be able to stop her from carrying out her suicide mission? Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: シャウト・トゥ・ザ・トップ!
Shout to the Top!
Shout to the Top!
Krzyk w niebiosa
Shout to the Top!
episode.summary: Dewey manages to destroy the Scub Control Cluster, sending debris floating on Trapar waves flying across the globe. Eureka and Renton try to control a badly damaged Nirvash, but they find unexpected resistance. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 星に願を
When You Wish Upon a Star
Una stella cade
Prośba do planety
Hoshi ni Negai o
episode.summary: The fate of the world is at stake as Eureka begins to turn into the next Scub Control Cluster. As an army of Coralians surround her, Renton understands that to save Eureka and everybody else, he might have to forsake his humanity. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 京田監督インタビュー
Interview with Director Kyouda
Kyouda Kantoku Interview
